G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the damages sought are within the jurisdictional limits of Massachusetts District Courts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the facts giving rise to this action occurred in Worcester, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 84, \u00a7 7A.proposition: Defendant Linda Greene, as the owner of the property at 123 Maple Street, had a legal duty to maintain the abutting sidewalk in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors, including timely removal of snow and ice, pursuant to G.L. c. 84, § 7A.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6F.proposition: Award Plaintiff reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6F or other applicable law;

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act constitutes negligence under Massachusetts common law as established in *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368 (2010), which held property owners liable for failures to address unnatural accumulations of snow and ice.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos does not impose liability only for failures to address *unnatural* accumulations; it expressly abolishes the natural/unnatural distinction and substitutes a general duty of reasonable care for all snow and ice hazards. The proposition misstates the holding by suggesting that liability turns on ‘unnatural accumulations,’ whereas the case’s core rule is that property owners owe the same reasonable-care duty for snow and ice as for any other hazard, regardless of whether the accumulation is natural or unnatural.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards… We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’”

*Sweeney v. Raoul*, 428 Mass. 579 (1998).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently found property owners liable for negligently maintaining icy sidewalks, where such conditions presented a foreseeable danger to lawful visitors.
*Sweeney v. Raoul*, 428 Mass. 579 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion in Sweeney v. Raoul does not concern premises liability, snow and ice, or duties of property owners to maintain sidewalks. It is a complex corporate/fiduciary litigation involving stock transfers, constructive trusts, and equitable remedies. Because the case nowhere addresses negligent maintenance of icy sidewalks or foreseeability of harm to lawful visitors, it cannot support the proposition stated.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently found property owners liable for negligently maintaining icy sidewalks, where such conditions presented a foreseeable danger to lawful visitors.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard concerns the abandonment of the invitee/licensee distinction and briefly discusses treatment of trespassers. It does not address liability for negligently maintaining icy sidewalks or any rule specific to snow and ice conditions on property. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority that Massachusetts courts have consistently imposed liability on property owners for icy sidewalks posing foreseeable dangers to lawful visitors.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that 'trespassers' stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

*Schiffman v. City of Boston*, 84 Mass..raw_text: *Schiffman v. City of Boston*, 84 Mass. App. Ct. 285 (2013)
*Schiffman v. City of Boston*, 84 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently found property owners liable for negligently maintaining icy sidewalks, where such conditions presented a foreseeable danger to lawful visitors.
*Schiffman v. City of Boston*, 84 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion text provided is not Schiffman v. City of Boston and does not concern premises liability, property owners, or icy sidewalk conditions. Instead, it is a criminal appeal involving a parent's murder conviction related to a child's death from medication overdose. Because the case does not address liability for negligently maintained icy sidewalks or foreseeability of danger to lawful visitors, it cannot support the cited proposition.
*Schiffman v. City of Boston*, 84 Mass..relevant_excerpt: No portion of the provided opinion discusses sidewalks, ice, snow, premises liability, or duties of property owners to lawful visitors; the entire opinion concerns criminal liability for a child's death due to medication overdose.

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act reasonably under the circumstances created a foreseeable and unreasonable risk of harm to Plaintiff and others, violating the standard of care outlined in cases including *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980), and *Deyesso v. Testa*, 406 Mass. 102 (1989).
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts a general negligence standard for landlords, holding that landlords, like other persons, must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm, and applies that standard to a tenant’s guest injured by a known defect. The court frames the key question as whether the landlord acted reasonably under the circumstances and finds that failure to repair a known dangerous railing, creating a foreseeable risk of harm to persons lawfully on the premises, can give rise to tort liability. This directly supports the proposition that an unreasonable failure to act in the face of a foreseeable risk violates the applicable standard of care.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk. … The question now must be whether the landlord, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered the defect and repaired it within a reasonable time.”

*Deyesso v. Testa*, 406 Mass. 102 (1989).proposition: Defendant’s failure to act reasonably under the circumstances created a foreseeable and unreasonable risk of harm to Plaintiff and others, violating the standard of care outlined in cases including *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980), and *Deyesso v. Testa*, 406 Mass. 102 (1989).
*Deyesso v. Testa*, 406 Mass. 102 (1989).support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case addressing due process limits on suggestive eyewitness identification procedures, not a negligence or tort standard-of-care case. It does not discuss whether a defendant failed to act reasonably under the circumstances or created a foreseeable and unreasonable risk of harm, nor does it reference or apply Young v. Garwacki or any similar duty-of-care framework. Citing Deyesso v. Testa here for a negligence standard-of-care proposition mischaracterizes the substance and holding of the opinion.
*Deyesso v. Testa*, 406 Mass. 102 (1989).relevant_excerpt: “Photographic identification procedures are constitutionally invalid if the procedures were ‘so impermissibly suggestive as to give rise to a very substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification.’ … After a defendant proves that an initial identification was impermissibly suggestive, the Commonwealth bears the burden to prove, by clear and convincing evidence, that any subsequent identifications are based on an independent source.”
